messageBody:
Sandy McArthur wrote:

>>5. Why not just put it in its own file? It's just as easy and not
>>at all hard to keep in sync.
>>
>>
>That's seperate from what I'm asking.
>
>The inner class method keeps everything together which is appealing,
>though it may not be logically consistant. I'm curious where it breaks
>down negativly.
>
>

This approach assumes unit tests map 1-to-1 with a class under test. I
tend to write tests that exercise and validate behavior which is not
necessarily encapsulated in a single class. If I were using the inner
class approach, I'm not sure which class would contain such tests.
